history.origin: Printed calendar sheets from 1909 with handwriting and illustrations added by Mary Behrend, found inside an envelope in a family baby album.

div2.fw: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.

figure.figDesc: Drawing of a woman in snowshoes named Molly pointing ahead of her. This is along the left-hand side of the page.

div2.ab:
Molly on
snowshoes
that Mr. Weir
got.
Pretty picture
is it not?!

div2.fw: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.

figure.figDesc: An infant is seen from behind. Looking closely, the image was made with a different type of paper. It was likely first printed in a magazine, cut out, and glued onto the page.

div2.ab:
That little spot in the
back of his neck
is the sweetest spot to
kiss I know
so I kiss him there
and hold him close
just because I love him so.
div2.note: It's clear that Mary is talking about her son Warren here. From the way she talks about him, he is a few months old (or less) and she absolutely adores him. If Warren is her first born child, then her joy from being around him makes a lot more sense.

div2.fw: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.

figure.figDesc: Two rabbits (or hares) next to each other. They are both dressed in fun and colorful clothing. This is right below the date on the middle of the page.

div2.note: I looks like Mary was in a creative mood on this day. Her drawing was quite playful and she also made a pun with the word "hare" meaning both "a rabbit" and "hair". The joke being that whaen you hear the words "hare dressing" you think about hair being stlyed but in this picture it refers to two rabbits wearing in clothes.

div2.fw: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.

figure.figDesc: A room is drawn, and within the room is a bed, nightstand with an alarm clock on it, and a window with a view of the sun rising above the horizon. A human is drawn getting out of bed and running over to the alarm clock to shut it off.

ab.add:
This is you sringing out
of bed, ready to murder
the alarm clock!

div2.note: Mary has drawn a picture of this bedroom scene and once again uses a pun. She says "an early spring". This both referenceing the person in the image getting out of bed early, and the season of spring coming early.

div2.fw: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.

figure.figDesc: A short man it a big a pencil behing his ear is shown holding up a piece of paper with a drawing on it. The drawing on the paper is of another goofy looking man. The image appears to be cut out (probably from a magazine) and pasted onto the page.

div2.note: The words "Look underneath, please!" are written on a sticky note. It is possible that there is more text underneath the sticky note.
